title: It Is Never Too Late: Managing Hearing Loss with Comorbidities
chief_complaint: I have trouble hearing, especially in background noise, and a bothersome buzzing in my ears. I also feel off-balance sometimes, though the room isn't spinning.

problem_summary.onset: Long-standing history of hearing loss; previous hearing aid trial 2 years ago was unsuccessful.
problem_summary.course: Progressive; slight decrease in thresholds over the last 2 years.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Bothersome tinnitus (7/10), intermittent dizziness/off-balance sensation, chronic coughing (COPD).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Struggling to participate in conversations; family feels she is withdrawing; tinnitus affects sleep.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Willing to try amplification again to help with hearing and tinnitus, despite previous failure.

history.present_illness: Patient returns 2 years after a failed hearing aid trial. Reports hearing loss and tinnitus (7/10 awareness and bothersomeness). Reports intermittent dizziness/lightheadedness but no vertigo.
history.otologic_history: Diagnosed with bilateral moderate-to-severe SNHL 2 years ago. Previous Dix-Hallpike negative, though Epley maneuver alleviated prior dizziness. No ear infections or surgeries.
history.medical_psych_history: COPD (chronic cough, uses inhalers), Hypothyroidism (Synthroid), Peripheral Neuropathy (Lyrica, Elavil), Sleep issues (Ambien), Vitamin D deficiency. Recent eval by neurologist for memory loss/cognitive decline.
history.prior_management: Tried custom half-shell ITEs 2 years ago; returned them after 1 month due to lack of acclimatization and medical burden.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Bilateral sloping moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss. Slight decrease in thresholds compared to 2 years ago. LDLs 85-90 dB HL.

tests.name: QuickSIN
tests.key_findings: Severe SNR loss. Performance improves significantly with increased loudness and visual cues.

history.prior_management: Decision made to try BTE style aids this time.

tests.name: Real Ear Measurements (REM)
tests.key_findings: Slim-tube BTE with power domes failed to meet NAL-NL1 targets. Switched to Receiver-In-Canal (RIC) with power domes, which met targets for 50, 65, and 80 dB SPL inputs.

history.present_illness: Follow-up visits revealed dexterity issues. Patient lost one RIC aid. Getting caught in hair/brush. Family assisting but process is tiresome.
history.patient_goals: Need a solution that is easier to handle and consistent.

tests.name: Extended-Wear Hearing Aid Fitting
tests.key_findings: Switched to extended-wear (deep insertion) devices. Patient reported own voice sounded 'echoic'. Reprogrammed to reduce low-frequency gain, which resolved the issue.

history.present_illness: Complication with extended-wear device. Patient's chronic coughing (COPD) dislodged the device, causing pain and redness.
history.prior_management: Left device removed to allow healing.

tests.name: Refitting
tests.key_findings: Inserted larger size device with lubrication to prevent slippage during coughing episodes. Patient reported tighter fit but comfortable. Subsequent follow-up showed no movement despite coughing.

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with bilateral sloping moderate-to-severe sensorineural hearing loss and significantly reduced dynamic range (LDLs 85-90 dB HL). Speech-in-noise ability is severely compromised (19.5 dB SNR loss) but improves dramatically with visual cues. Tinnitus is a significant comorbid factor initially rated 7/10.
counseling_points: Hearing aids are 'medicine for the brain'â€”they must be used consistently to be effective.
Visual cues are essential for your understanding; look at the speaker.
Your medications and conditions (COPD, thyroid) can contribute to dizziness and tinnitus.
Consistent auditory stimulation can help reduce tinnitus perception.
notes_for_actor: Portray an 87-year-old with COPD; include occasional coughing fits.
Initially, speak loudly and laugh at inappropriate times (due to not hearing).
After treatment (V3/V4), soften your voice and show appropriate humor/personality.
Express frustration with handling small objects (dexterity issues).
When asked about tinnitus after treatment, respond with 'What tinnitus?' to show relief.
